results.title: The legacy of Len Lye
results.brief_description:
Tyler Cann talks about the works on display in the Len Lye exhibition at ACMI and the legacy of an extraordinary artist. Tyler Cann is the Curator of the Len Lye Collection at the Govett-Brewster Art Gallery, New Zealand.
Interview recorded in July 2009.
results.description:

results.title: TV50 Celebrity Interviews
results.creator_credit: Astrid Scott, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: Interviews with thirteen celebrities from Australian television. Asked the same questions, their responses are recorded vox pop style. Questions asked concern the celebrities’ experiences of television both as a viewer and as a personality and performer as well as their thoughts on reality television and the state of Australian television in general. Interviews were conducted at ACMI for the TV50 exhibition in 2006.

results.title: Mary and Max: The Exhibition: interview with Adam Elliot March 2010
results.brief_description: Oscar winning animation director and writer Adam Elliot speaks candidly about his stop frame animation processes and, more importantly, about why he makes films. Adam also talks about the challenges he faced during the making of his first feature film ‘Mary and Max’.

results.title: An Interview with Gillian Armstrong
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Shelley Matulick and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Award-winning Australian film and documentary director Gillian Armstrong’s film career spans over 40 years locally and internationally.

Here she shares her discovery of Orry-Kelly and the incredibly fortunate set of events that uncovered his memoir and his box of memorabilia including his three Oscars.

The release of Armstrong’s 2015 feature-length documentary on the life and work of renowned costume designer Orry-Kelly, ‘Women He’s Undressed’, coincided with ACMI’s exhibition ‘Orry-Kelly: Dressing Hollywood’.

results.title: Tusalava
results.brief_description: 1. Lye’s first film was originally accompanied by live music by Jack Ellit. No score was ever found, so the film presented here is silent, a vision of the beginnings of life on earth - mixing Maori, silent and modernist influences.

results.title: Archival prints
results.brief_description:
1. Where the River Kiewa Flows - Focuses on the Kiewa Butter Factory and how it is using excess skim and butter milk to provide food for its piggery. By doing this it is increasing its profits and reducing waste. The Victorian Department of Agriculture’s ‘Pig Expert’ devised a plan for maximum efficiency of the piggery, taking into account that there would be more excess milk in the summer than the winter.

Contains footage of the Kiewa piggery as well as the butter production plant and surrounding district, which all look good.

  1. The Challenge - Film carries an inspirational message and is largely concerned with the need for all Victorians to consolidate their current strong agricultural position by embracing ‘progress’ and moving forward with new ideas. Very earnest throughout.

Opens with dissolves between Melbourne cityscapes and then focuses on numerous, well-shot general agricultural and farm scenes from the late 1950s. This includes shots of wheat farming, grain export, livestock and the people behind it.

Last shots are of Melbourne. The final one being a pan, shot from above, down St Kilda Rd away from the city, towards the Shrine of Rememberance.

Excellent titles/the end.

results.title: Green Fingers: Planting Evergreens
results.brief_description: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Planting Evergreens’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to correctly plant evergreen trees and shrubs in your garden, accompanied by a narrator explaining the method and techniques. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.
results.description: Green Fingers was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. The episodes of Green Fingers are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of Sow What, Better Homes and Gardens, and Gardening Australia.

results.title: Phalaris seed retention
results.brief_description:
In order to negate Phelaris crops from losing their ‘top’ before harvesting, crop-dusting is employed.

Features good footage of plane flying over crops and releasing chemicals.

Largely comprises of an interview between a presenter and a scientist.

results.title: Fashions for Men
results.creator_credit: Mel F. Nichols, Frank Coffey, Winifred Lade, John Maynard and Department of Information
results.brief_description: Produced by the Department of Information, this government propaganda film shows the manufacture of uniforms in factories for the Australian armed forces serving in the Second World War. The film begins with an opening sequence that chronicles the development of Australia’s armed forces since colonisation in 1788, showing the styles of uniform worn over the decades by soldiers making “glorious history”. The film then explores the mass production and assembly lines of the various equipment required for contemporary uniforms including silk parachutes, khaki wool clothing, brass badges, tin and felt hats, and gas masks. The film is a fascinating insight into factory production of the period, and an example of propaganda encouraging patriotic values in support of Australia’s armed forces. As with many instructional films of the period, the film reflects now outdated gender stereotypes, showing women working in assembly lines sewing on buttons, while men work with steel machinery.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mel F. Nichols, Frank Coffey, Winifred Lade, John Maynard and Department of Information
